Graphical abstract Low temperature catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 plays an important role in flue gas treatments. Here, a two-dimensional MnFeCo layered double oxide were synthetized, characterized and employed as NH3 selective catalytic reduction catalyst, showing excellent low temperature de-NOx performance. MnFeCo layered double oxide exhibited a specific surface area of 92 m2/g with average pore size and volume of 2 nm and 1.5 cm3/g. At 100 °C, the MnFeCo layered double oxide performed an efficient NO conversion of 100 %. Even at 25 and 50 °C, NO conversions reached values of 49 and 86 %, respectively. Furthermore, the NO conversion reached an efficiency of 89 % in the presence of H2O vapor (5 %) and SO2 (100 ppm). Based on that, it can be said that this NH3 selective catalytic reduction catalyst shows great potential in NOx denitration of stationary industrial installations at a low temperature range. Keywords Layered double oxide Selective catalytic reduction Denitration catalyst Stationary industrial installation 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are the main air pollutants, which directly or indirectly cause many environmental problems including acid fog, haze, and intensified ozone depletion [1–3]. Most of the NOx are derived from stationary industrial installations (∼ 70 %), such as coal-fired power plants and industrial boilers [4]. Nowadays, ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) technology is the most promising approach to solve the problem of NOx pollution [5–7], where the most widely used selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalyst is V2O5-WO3/TiO2. This material has excellent denitration (NOx-de) activity, but it has a high cost and a high operating temperature window (>350 °C) [7]. In order to reach this operating temperature, the SCR catalyst bed is generally placed in front of the air preheater, the precipitator and the desulfurization bed [8]. At this time, both fly ash and sulfur dioxide (SO2) in flue gas will enter the catalyst reactor, resulting in catalyst blockage and poisoning, shortening the functional time life [8,9]. In order to overcome these shortcomings, academia and industry have been working on developing new low temperature SCR materials and technologies [1]. One of these new technological options implies that the SCR catalyst is installed behind the dust removal and desulfurization device to alleviate the poisoning and clogging of the catalyst by SO2 and dust [10–12]. However, the main problem with this arrangement is that the exhaust gas temperature is low [8]. Therefore, in order to reach the required temperature before the flue gas enters to the catalyst reactor, it is necessary to install a burner or steam-heated heat exchanger to heat the flue gas, but this will inevitably increase the energy consumption and operation costs [13]. Hence, the development of low-temperature SCR catalysts with good low-temperature activity, high selectivity, good stability and wide operating temperature would not only avoid the preheating energy process, but also to reduce the denitration costs [14–16]. Usually, manganese oxides (MnOx) have excellent NH3-SCR performance at low temperatures [17]. However, NH3-SCR performance of composite oxide catalysts, containing manganese and other metals, can be remarkably improve the catalytic performance, in comparison to single oxide catalysts [18]. The addition of other transition elements can enhance the catalytic activity, by adjusting or changing the electronic and morphological structure of the catalyst [19]. For example, Gao et al. [8] found that the deep dehydrogenation of the coordinated NH3, with a lower MnAO (A = Co, Ni) energy band will increase the selectivity and specifically the MnNiOx catalyst achieved a total NO conversion (100 %) at 200 °C. In 2018, Zhao et al. [19] found that Mn(Al)Ox lattice distortion can promote the formation of oxygen vacancies, reaching 100 % of SCR of NO at 200 °C. At the same time, Fang et al. [20] prepared a Fe–Mn–Zr oxide catalyst, which removed 100 % NO at 200 °C, and they found that the multi-element interaction improved the lattice oxygen migration capacity, as well as the redox performance. In 2019, Tian et al. [21] reported that the multi-component Mn-Ce-Fe-Ti catalytic system had a higher oxygen superficial adsorption, inducing a rapid and highly efficient NH3-SCR; 100 % of NO conversion at 250 °C. In addition, it has been found that the performance of all these multi-elemental catalysts can also be improved by changing the support [19]. The catalyst support not only holds the active components, but it induces appropriate shape and particle size, as well as it provides appropriate pore size and specific surface area for the catalyst deposition, and adjusts the acidity and alkalinity [22]. In 2016, Li et al. [23] loaded Mn on TiO2 to completely remove NO at 150 °C, and they found that larger specific surface areas were beneficial to the catalyst dispersion promoting the SCR reaction. Later, Wang et al. [24] successfully loaded MnOx onto a CeO2-Al2O3 support and completely removed NO at 200 °C, and these authors found that Mn4+ contributes to promote a low temperature activity. Zhang et al. [4] found that high BET surface area of the MnOx-Fe2O3/VMT catalyst system are beneficial to increase the number of active sites, and 96 % of NO can be removed at 200 °C. However, despite all these works reported on literature, a highly efficient denitrification catalyst working at around 100 °C is still a great scientific challenge. It is well reported on literature that, layered double oxide (LDO) catalysts not only have a unique two-dimensional structure, but also have large specific surface areas with large amounts of active sites [19,25]. Moreover, LDO samples containing Co3+ and Fe3+ species are more advantageous for redox properties, although these elements can play a key role in enhancing the whole catalytic activity [26,27]. Moreover, it has been reported that iron addition to MnOx tend to inhibit the sulfation process, increasing its sulfur resistance [20]. On the other hand, Co3O4 catalyst also exhibits excellent resistance to water and sulfur, having a high oxidizing ability [28–31]. Thus, the addition of cobalt can form a large amount of Brønsted acid sites, favoring the NH3 adsorption [32]. In the MnxCo3-xO4 catalyst, the strong interaction of manganese and cobalt oxide species inhibits the formation of manganese sulfate, improving the oxide stability and sulfur tolerance [33]. Based on these reports, the aim of the present work was to synthesize and evaluate a MnFeCo-LDO material for the SCR of NO at low temperatures (25−150 °C). Moreover, it was analyzed the effect produced by the water vapor and SO2 addition on the SCR performance. 2 Experimental section Manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)2 AR, Macklin), cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2 AR, Macklin) and iron nitrate (Fe(NO3)3 AR, Macklin), with Mn:Co:Fe molar ratios of 1:1:0, 1:0:1 and 1:1:1, were dissolved in deionized water to form a series of metal salt solutions (total metal cation concentration of 1 mol/L). Then, each metal salt solution was dropped into a sodium carbonate solution (Na2CO3, 0.5 M) under intense stirring, and the pH value was maintained at 10, by slightly adding drop by drop a sodium hydroxide solution (NaOH, 2 M). During the synthesis process, oxygen or air should be continuously flowed to favor the manganese oxidation. These suspensions were aged overnight at room temperature, washed with distilled water, and dried at 60 °C to obtain the hydrotalcite or layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors. These precursors were labeled as MnCo-LDH, MnFe-LDH and MnFeCo-LDH. Finally, in order to obtain the corresponding LDO samples, all the LDH precursors were calcined at 500 °C for 4 h and labeled as MnFe-LDO, MnCo-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO, based on the transition metal chemical compositions. The crystal structure and microstructure of these samples were characterized by different techniques. X-ray diffraction (XRD; model D8 ADVANCE, Bruker, Germany) was performed using a Cu-Kα radiation source. The voltage was 40 kV, while the current was 40 mA, and the scanning range was 10°≤ 2θ ≤90°. The microscopic images were obtained by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) operated at 10 kV (Hitachi S-4800), while transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken from a JEOL-2010 F electron microscope (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) operating at 200 kV. The N2 adsorption-desorption characteristics of these catalysts, such as the specific surface areas, pore volumes, and pore sizes, were analyzed using a US ASP2020C N2 equipment (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.). Each catalyst was firstly degassed under vacuum at 100 °C. Then, the N2 adsorption-desorption tests were carried out at −196 °C. The computer software provided with the instrument automatically calculated all the textural characteristics described above, using the corresponding BET and BJH models. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer) was used to determine the valence and semi-quantitatively analyze the transition element contents in each catalyst. Mg radiation source was used; the voltage was 120 kV, and the current was 20 mA. Measurements of surface acidity of the catalysts were determined by NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), using a Quantachrome AMI-90 equipment. The surface acidity of the catalysts were acquired between 100 and 600 °C, using a linear heating rate of 2 °C/min under Ar flow (40 mL/min). The reduction performance of all the catalyst samples was characterized by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR; American Micromeritics model ASAP 2720 multipurpose equipment). The samples were treated with N2 at 100 °C for 20 min, cooled down and passed through a 10 % of H2/Ar mixture. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) automatically recorded the data over the temperature range of 25–900 °C. After the characterization process, the efficiency of these catalysts in the NH3-SCR reaction was measured using a fixed-bed microreactor. The reactor was composed of a stainless steel tube with a 10.0 mm inner diameter. Quartz sand and quartz wool were placed in the reactor to ensure that the powdered catalyst was in the middle of the reaction tube, and the thermocouple was placed directly above the sample powder. Then, the reactor is placed in the middle of the furnace to ensure better temperature gradient control. During the tests, the reaction tube was filled with 0.3 g of a powdered catalyst and the outlet gas concentration was recorded over the temperature range of 25–400 °C. At the feed side, the gas composition was 500 ppm of NO ([NO]in), 500 ppm of NH3 ([NH3]in), and 5 % of oxygen, nitrogen balance. The total flow rate of the reaction gas was 100 mL/min, representing a GHSV of 30,600 h−1. The gas concentrations, recorded as [NH3]out, [NO]out, [NO2]out, and [N2O]out, were measured by FTIR (Thermo Fisher IS10, USA) at the end of the reaction tube. Thus, Eqs. 3 and 4 are represented by; V was the total flow rate (mL/s), and W was the mass of catalyst (g), k was the pseudo-first order rate constant, Ea was the reaction activation energy, A was the pre-exponential factor and R was the gas constant (8.314 J/molK). All performance results in this paper are repeated at least twice to ensure reproducibility, and data was recorded only when the SCR reaction reached the steady state after 40 min of continuous operation at each temperature. The performance of the catalysts was characterized using the following formulas (Eqs. 1–4): (1) [ N O ] c o n v e r s i o n = N O i n - N O o u t NO i n ×1 00 % (2) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = 1 - 2 N 2 O o u t + NO 2 out N O i n + NH 3 i n - N O out - NH 3 out × 100 % (3) k = - V W × ln 1 - N O c o n v e r s i o n (4) ln k = ln A - E a / R T The conversion of NO at different temperatures is calculated from the data measured by FTIR (Eq. 1). The NO conversion of 298, 323, and 348 K are taken to calculate the value of k (Eq. 3). Then, the logarithm of k (ln k) is taken, as well as the inverse of temperature (1/T). There is a linear relationship between ln k and 1/T [33–35], where -Ea/R is the slope and ln A is the intercept. Using ln k as the ordinate and 1/T as the abscissa, a straight line can be fitted from three different temperature points. 3 Results and discussion The morphology of MnFe-LDH, MnCo-LDH and MnFeCo-LDH samples was observed by FE-SEM. It can be seen, from Fig. 1 a–c, that the MnFeCo-LDH, MnCo-LDH samples have the typical nano-sheet morphology, distinctive of layered double hydroxides [10,11]. The shape, distribution and order of the ternary MnFeCo-LDH nanosheets are more regular and they have a small particle size distribution of 200−300 nm, in comparison to the MnCo-LDH sample (particle size ≥500 nm). On the contrary, the MnFe-LDH sample showed dense, disordered and importantly large particles (around 50−80 nm), which tend to agglomerate (≥500 nm). In addition to the morphological analysis, the Fig. 1d shows the XRD patterns of the three samples. MnCo-LDH and MnFeCo-LDH samples have a double layered hydroxide structure (hydrotalcite-like crystal phase), with small amounts of manganese carbonate phase [36]. The MnFe-LDH sample only showed the corresponding diffraction peaks of manganese carbonate. Based on these results, it can be established that Mn and Fe-Co occupy and preserved the M2+ and M3+ cation crystal positions, respectively, atomic positions usually occupied by Mg2+ and Al3+ on the typical LDH system. These results are in good agreement with the SEM results, confirming that only MnCo-LDH and MnFeCo-LDH samples presented the typical LDH crystal structure and morphology. After the structural and microstructural characterization of the LDH samples, all of them were thermally treated as it was described above (see experimental section) and the resulting LDO powders were re-characterized. Fig. 2 a shows the XRD patterns of the three samples, evidencing the LDH and MnCO3 thermal decomposition to amorphous and partially crystal oxides. Specifically, Mn2O3 (PDF file 33-0900), Mn3O4 (PDF file 24-0734) and Fe2O3 (PDF file 33-0664) crystal phases were identified. Thus, manganese atoms were oxidized from Mn2+ to Mn3+ and Mn4+, as it would be expected. In the iron case, it stayed at its highest oxidation state (Fe3+), while none cobalt oxide or compound was detected. In such a case, cobalt should be incorporated as doping element on iron and manganese oxides or been part of the amorphous phase. After the structural characterization of the LDO samples, they were further characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, HR-TEM and XPS. All these samples presented N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms type II with different hysteresis loops [37], indicating the presence of different mesoporosities (Fig. 2b). MnFe-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO samples possess narrow hysteresis type H3, while MnCo-LDO sample presented a hysteresis loop type H1. It means that MnFe-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO samples have non-rigid aggregates of plate-like particles with slit-shape pores, but MnCo-LDO sample has well-defined cylindrical-like pore channels. These porosity differences are consistent with the mean pore diameters determined by the BJH model, where MnCo-LDO sample has a well defined mono-modal pore size centered at 22 nm, while MnFe-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO samples have wider pore size distributions, varying from 10 to 50 nm. Moreover, these results can be related to the specific surface areas determined by the BET model, where MnCO-LDO sample presented a smaller value (79 m2/g) than those obtained on the other two samples; 91 and 92 m2/g for MnFe-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO samples, respectively. These results indicate that iron addition increases the specific surface area of the samples. Moreover, the particle size and morphology of the samples did not present any significant change (data not shown) in comparison to the corresponding LDH samples presented above. In fact, Xia et al. [7] reported that iron addition on similar oxide systems improves the pore structure of the catalysts. In addition, it has been found that higher specific surface area provides more available surface active sites on catalysts, enhancing the catalytic activity [38]. In the present case, the ternary MnFeCo-LDO catalyst has the largest pore volume, pore size and specific surface area, in comparison to both binary LDO systems, which are important factors of an excellent catalytic performance [1,7]. The redox behavior of these catalysts was investigated using H2-TPR analysis, as it is shown in Fig. 2c. Initially, the reduction process of the MnFe-LDO sample can be expressed as the corresponding reduction of the metal oxides previously detected by XRD, Fe2O3 and Mn2O3 (see Fig. 2a). Previous studies demonstrated that the peak at 389 °C is assigned to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3, and the peak at 465 °C is attributable to the simultaneous reduction of Fe2O3 and Mn2O3 [39]. The reduction peak above 571 °C is related to the simultaneous reduction of Mn3O4 and FeO [61,62]. For the MnCo-LDO catalyst, the three main reduction reactions occurred at 350, 405 and 522 °C. There is a shoulder at around 350 °C, which is attributed to the Mn4+ reduction to Mn2O3 [40], while the peak centered at around 405 °C is due to the further manganese reduction from Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and the conversion of Co3 2+,3+O4 → Co2+O [41,42]. The reduction peak near 522 °C belongs to the simultaneous reduction of Mn3O4 → MnO and Co2+ → Co° [39,64]. In Fig. 2c, the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst showed three peaks at 327, 397 and 567 °C. The first two reduction peaks (T < 500 °C) of MnFeCo-LDO catalyst moved to lower temperature, in comparison to the MnFe- and MnCo-LDO samples. It shows that the double addition of Co and Fe improves the low temperature redox ability [43]. Different works have proved that the variation of TPR peak positions can be attributed to many different factors, such as lattice oxygen mobility, phase composition and structural defects [39,44]. In this case, the peak area reduction of the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is larger than that of MnFe-LDO (1.1:1), and it increased at low temperature. This result indicates a high oxygen mobility, because amorphous metal oxides were formed and oxygen transfer was easier to be released at low temperature. So, it can be expected that the Co addition causes a synergetic effect between manganese, iron and cobalt species, producing oxygen defects and enhancing the reducing ability of this catalyst for the SCR reaction [32,42,43,45]. Additionally, NH3-TPD experiments were performed to study the surface acidity of these catalysts (Fig. 2d). MnFeCo-LDO, MnFe-LDO, and MnCo-LDO samples have acidic sites below 500 °C, which are attributed to the continuous desorption of physically adsorbed ammonia [25]. According to literature, NH3 molecules adsorbed on the Brönsted acid sites are released more easily than those adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [46]. Therefore, these desorption peaks, at the low temperature region (< 400 °C), belongs to the Brönsted acid sites, while the desorption peak of at the higher temperature region (> 400 °C) can be assigned to the Lewis acid sites [20,47]. By integrating the NH3-TPD curves, the MnFeCo-LDO, MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO peak areas were 199, 131 and 101. These results indicate that the surface acidity of the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is the highest one, followed by MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO catalysts [48]. In addition, the ternary MnFeCo-LDO catalyst has more Brönsted acid sites in the low temperature section. Thus, the peak area of the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is significantly increased after the addition of the Fe element. It shows that the addition of Fe improves the acidity of the catalyst surface [7,49]. Yu et al. [50] found out that the decrease in the acidity of Brönsted acid sites is related to the decrease in NO conversion, indicating that the Brönsted acid sites play an important role in the catalytic conversion of NO. Therefore, surface acidity is considered to be closely related to catalytic activity [46]. It has been found that an improvement in the acidity of the surface of the SCR catalyst can inhibit the oxidation of ammonia at high temperatures, increase catalytic activity and N2 selectivity [7]. Appropriate surface acid sites can adsorb and activate NH3, an important step in reducing NO with NH3 to improve SCR performance and N2 selectivity [51]. Long et al. [52] also found that ammonia species can be adsorbed on acidic materials to produce NH4 + and coordinated NH3 species and react with nitrogen oxides to improve catalytic performance. In summary, due to the addition of cobalt and iron, the surface acidity of the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is increased, improving the catalytic activity and selectivity, which is consistent with these catalytic activity test results. HR-TEM images of the MnFe-LDO, MnCo-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO samples are shown in Fig. 3 . MnCo-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO samples presented homogeneous crystal size distribution of around ∼10 nm, while MnFe-LDO sample presented an interconnected and larger crystal size distribution (5−30 nm). Further analysis of these crystal images showed a lattice fringe of 0.203 nm, corresponding to the (220) Mn3O4 crystal plane (Fig. 3f), and the lattice fringes of 0.186, 0.222 and 0.252 nm are the (024), (113) and (110) crystal planes of Mn2O3 (Fig. 3b and d). In addition, it was found a lattice fringe of 0.34 nm, corresponding to the (116) crystal plane of Fe2O3 (Figure b). The presence of these metal oxides corroborate the XRD and TPD results, showing that LDO samples are composed by metal oxide mixtures. Moreover, TEM analysis did not evidence the presence of any crystalline cobalt compound, either. In addition to the crystal analysis performed by TEM, it was obtained the mapping elemental distribution for the MnFeCo-LDO sample, presented in the same Fig. 3. This analysis show a homogeneous Mn, Fe, Co and O elemental distribution, an important surface characteristic needed for almost any catalytic process. Therefore, different metal oxides were obtained on the LDO samples, although they are highly dispersed on the material bulk. The surface atomic composition and valence states of MnFeCo-LDO, MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO samples were studied by XPS. Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra of Mn-2p, Co-2p, Fe-2p and O-1s of all these samples and Table 1 summarizes the surface atomic concentrations after the spectra peak-fitting deconvolution. The Mn 2p3/2 spectrum can be divided into three peaks: 641.0–641.3 eV (Mn2+), 642.8–1642.7 eV (Mn3+) and 643.4–644.2 eV(Mn4+) and according to literature [53], the order of activity of MnOx species is: MnO2 > Mn5O8 > Mn2O3 > Mn3O4 > MnO. This trend indicates that a high ratio of Mn4+/Mn(Mn2++Mn3++Mn4+) is favorable for increasing NO conversion. Thus, if a large amount of active MnO2 is formed on the surface of MnFeCo-LDO, it contributes to improve the low-temperature catalytic activity. In fact, MnFeCo-LDO sample has the largest Mn4+ amount (49 %), in comparison to MnCo-LDO (23 %) and MnFeOx (22 %) samples, indicating that the Co and Fe simultaneous addition enhances the Mn oxidation. It must be pointed out that binding energies, of ternary MnFeCo-LDO catalyst, move to lower values, in comparison with the binary MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO samples. These binding energy shifts indicate that there is a strong interaction between the Mn, Fe and Co species, which may promote an increase in the outer electron cloud density of Mn, and the shielding effect is improved [7], improving the electron transfer and redox performance [7]. The Fe 2p XPS spectra of MnFeCo-LDO and MnFe-LDO catalysts are shown in Fig. 4b. Two different peaks were observed at 710 and 724 eV, which, based on literature, can be attributed to Fe-2p3/2 and Fe-2p1/2, respectively [25,54]. The Fe2+ species peak positions are located at 709.9–710.6 eV and 725.2–726.4 eV [25,54], while peaks of 711.8–713.8 eV and 723.1–723.3 eV are attributed to Fe3+ species [25,54,55]. Thus, it is clear that the Fe3+ content of MnFeCo-LDO catalyst decreases after cobalt addition compared with that of MnFe-LDO catalyst (Table 1). Fig. 4c shows the binding energy differences between the main peaks of Co-2p3/2 and Co-2p1/2, which is about 15.3 eV, representing the characteristics of Co3O4 phase previously reported [8,26,56]. The Co-2p3/2 and Co-2p1/2 peaks can be deconvoluted on four signals, 779.7–779.8 (Co3+), 781.1–781.6 (Co2+), 795.0–795.1 (Co3+) and 796.6–797.0 (Co2+) [8,57]. Co3+ species are more favorable for redox properties and they play a key role in enhancing catalytic activity [8,26,58]. The Co3+/Co ratio of MnFeCo-LDO sample increases after adding iron (Table 1), indicating that the surface of ternary catalyst has more Co3+ species. The O-1s XPS spectra of the MnFeCo-LDO, MnFe-LDO, MnCo-LDO catalysts can be fitted to several peaks (Fig. 4d). The peak at a lowest binding energy (529.2–529.3 eV) can be attributed to lattice oxygen (Oα), while the peak at a higher binding energy (529.6–531.7 eV) corresponds to oxygen adsorbed (Oβ) [48]. From Table 1, the Oβ/(Oα+Oβ) ratio of MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is the highest one, which means that the ternary mixed metal oxide lead to a higher surface oxygen vacancies [25]. Surface adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) has been reported to play a key role in the SCR reaction due to its higher mobility [59–61]. Liu et al. [62] found that Oβ contributes to the oxidation of NO to NO2, promoting a rapid SCR reaction. Here, the Oβ/(Oα+Oβ) ratio of MnFeCo-LDO sample is significantly higher than those of MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO catalysts. In addition, the Oα and Oβ binding energies of MnFeCo-LDO are lower than those of MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO samples, which indicates that the ternary mixed metal oxide has the highest electron density, promoting the generation of more reactive electrophilic oxygen species [63]. In summary, the addition of cobalt and iron significantly increased the surface oxygen content as well as the Mn4+ content which must improve the low temperature denitration performance on the MnFeCo-LDO sample. After the complete structural, microstructural and superficial characterizations of these samples (MnFe-LDO, MnCo-LDO and MnFeCo-LDO), all of them were tested for the NH3-SCR activity, as a possible application. In fact, it was determined based on the whole analysis of these materials, giving a special attention to the superficial analysis, which showed adequate characteristics for this catalytic reaction process. From Fig. 5 a, it can be seen that the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst can remove 49 % of NO at 25 °C, and this catalytic activity is higher than those observed on the MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO catalysts, at the same temperature. It must be pointed out that all these LDO materials presented important catalytic activities (25–49 %) at 25 °C. It means that catalytic process began as soon as the NO gas is flowed into the LDO samples. In addition, the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst removes more than 86 % of NO in the temperature range of 50−400 °C, while the active temperature range of MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO is limited to 100−250 °C. Considering the temperature range of the catalytic evaluation, these results can be considered as superior to other results previously reported on literature (Table 2 ). Specifically MnFeCo-LDO system analyzed at 100 °C, or lower temperatures, are comparable with all the data presented this table, where all these systems only present NO conversions of 100 % at higher temperatures. At T ≤ 100 °C, the highest NO conversions reported were obtained using Ni-MnOx (73 % [8]), MnOx-CeO2 (87 % [63]) and MnFe-TiO2 (89 % [62]), where it must be pointed out that Ni-MnOx and MnOx-CeO2 systems used similar GHSV than that reported in the present work (around 25,000–30,000 h−1), while the MnFe-TiO2 system used a higher GHSV (120,000 h−1). In other words, none of these reports presented full NO conversions at 100 °C. Moreover, MnFeCo-LDO sample has even excellent NO conversions at 25 and 50 °C, around 49 and 86 % respectively. It means that this specific system has a very good catalytic behavior without the necessity of any heating process. The reaction rate constant k is an important physical value in chemical kinetics, and it directly reflects the magnitude of the reaction rate. Moreover, Fig. 6 shows the Arrhenius type plot comparing the three samples, where it can be seen that all of them present very similar trends and activation energies. Thus, assuming that Ea is constant, it can be compared the pseudo-first order rate constants (k) [67,68], where it can be found that MnFeCo–LDO catalyst has the largest reaction rate constants at 25, 50 and 100 °C (see Table 2). In summary, no matter from the consideration of the NO conversion and reaction rate constant, MnFeCo–LDO catalyst shows an excellent catalytic performance. The N2 selectivity of the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is always maintained above 86 % between 50 and 150 °C. It should be mentioned that MnFeCo-LDO sample maintains the N2 selectivity above 51 % in the high temperature range, while on MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO catalysts the N2 selectivity falls below 30 % at higher temperatures than 250 °C. In addition, the ternary MnFeCo-LDO catalyst produced the lowest NO2 and N2O amounts. For MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO samples N2O concentration increases rapidly after 150 °C, while the NO2 concentration increased sharply after 200 °C. Conversely, on the ternary MnFeCo-LDO sample the N2O and NO2 concentrations grew slightly. Based on these results, it is evident that the selectivity of the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst is significantly increased due to iron addition. Iron increases the surface acidity and subsequently the N2 selectivity. This result is consistent with the NH3-TPD results and literature. All these results can be explained based on the multiple oxidation state presented by the transition metals, which create surface defects (vacancies), favoring the sorption and catalytic processes needed in the NH3-SCR. For example, Begum et al. [49] found that the addition of Fe can significantly improve the acidity of the catalyst surface, which helps to improve the N2 selectivity. Moreover, Chen et al. [39] found that the addition of Fe can improve low temperature catalytic performance and N2 selectivity. Xia et al. [7] found that the addition of Fe increased catalytic performance and N2 selectivity. If denitrification activities of MnCo-LDO and MnFe-LDO catalysts are compared, it is shown that in the low temperature range MnCo-LDO catalyst has a higher activity than that of MnFe-LDO, because MnCo-LDO has a higher concentration of Mn4+ and oxygen adsorbed at the catalyst surface. In summary, for the MnFeCo-LDO case, the addition of iron increases the N2 selectivity, while cobalt addition enhances the low temperature activity. For this application, a real flue gas still has water vapor and small amounts of SO2, which usually has a negative effect on the catalyst activity. Fig. 7 shows the resistance of MnFeCo-LDO, MnFe-LDO, MnCo-LDO catalysts to water and sulfur dioxide at 120 °C and GHSV of 30,600 h−1. When 5 % H2O was added, the activity of MnFe-LDO catalyst highly decreased by 20 %, while the MnCo-LDO catalytic activity decreased by 12 %. However, the ternary MnFeCo-LDO catalyst still has a high conversion of 94 %, after water addition. After that, 100 ppm of SO2 were added to the system, and the conversion of the three catalysts slightly decreased. Among them, the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst presented the lowest decrement, as the conversion only decreased by around 2 %. It can be seen that H2O has a greater influence on the activity of the catalysts at 120 °C. Based on these results, the most stable catalyst (MnFeCo-LDO) was tested at 100 °C. At this temperature, the MnFeCo-LDO catalytic activity decreased by 8 %, after adding 5 % H2O, and by 2 % after introducing SO2. Thus, at a lower temperature H2O and SO2 have a higher influence on MnFeCo-LDO catalyst during the NH3-SCR reaction. It can be explained by the large amount of water vapor adsorption, as well as the NO/NH3 adsorption competition on the catalyst surface [20,45]. Finally, after removing water and sulfur dioxide from the flue gas, the conversion of the three catalysts recovered to some extent, but only the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst returned to the initial level at 120 °C. In the MnFe-LDO and MnCo-LDO samples the catalytic activities were only recovered to 79 and 88 %, respectively. It seemed that H2O addition was the main responsible of the catalytic decrements presents by these two samples, and it may be produced by a partial rehydroxylation of these layered double oxides to layered double hydroxides. In such a cases, the microstructural and superficial chemical properties must have changed, reducing their catalytic activities. Thus, the ternary MnFeCo-LDO catalyst has a better resistance to water (rehydroxylation) and sulfur dioxide at 120 °C, than MnCo-LDO and MnFe-LDO samples. 4 Conclusions A low temperature SCR catalyst MnFeCo-LDO capable of resisting the influence of water and sulfur dioxide is obtained by calcining the corresponding hydrotalcite-like precursor. Other two catalyst were prepared, MnCo-LDO and MnFe-LDO samples for comparison purposes. The MnFeCo-LDO catalyst completely removed NO at 100 °C, and the selectivity of N2 was 90 %. Even 49 % NO can be removed at 25 °C, having a 98 % of N2 selectivity. MnFeCo-LDO catalyst can achieve NO conversion over 86 % and N2 selectivity over 50 % in a wide temperature range (50−400 °C). Among all these samples, the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst has the largest specific surface area, high content of Mn4+ and surface oxygen content, as well as the largest amount of acidic sites. Thus, it was found that the addition of iron is beneficial to increase the specific surface area, enhancing the surface acidity, and the N2 selectivity. At the same time, cobalt addition increases the surface oxygen content and reducing ability, and enhance the water and sulfur resistance. Therefore, the MnFeCo-LDO catalyst can be used as a low-cost and environmentally friendly low-temperature NH3-SCR catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Low temperature catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 plays an important role in flue gas treatments. Here, a two-dimensional MnFeCo layered double oxide were synthetized, characterized and employed as NH3 selective catalytic reduction catalyst, showing excellent low temperature de-NOx performance. MnFeCo layered double oxide exhibited a specific surface area of 92 m2/g with average pore size and volume of 2 nm and 1.5 cm3/g. At 100 °C, the MnFeCo layered double oxide performed an efficient NO conversion of 100 %. Even at 25 and 50 °C, NO conversions reached values of 49 and 86 %, respectively. Furthermore, the NO conversion reached an efficiency of 89 % in the presence of H2O vapor (5 %) and SO2 (100 ppm). Based on that, it can be said that this NH3 selective catalytic reduction catalyst shows great potential in NOx denitration of stationary industrial installations at a low temperature range.
coredata.dc:title: Two-dimensional MnFeCo layered double oxide as catalyst for enhanced selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 at low temperature (25–150 °C)
